thread.title: Raury gives us 'All We Need' on new album
thread.title_full: Raury gives us 'All We Need' on new album

title: Raury gives us 'All We Need' on new album
text:
Raury gives us 'All We Need' on new album Jeffrey Lee Puckett , @JLeePuckett 8:29 a.m. EDT October 12, 2015 Raury, "All We Need" CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Atlanta's hip-hop scene is the most interesting in the country, filled with artists willing to try anything. Raury, 20, is expected to be one of the scene's leading lights for years with his mix of hip-hop, indie rock, folk and soul. 
"All We Need," out this week, is his second full-length. He does much of his own production but gets contributions from an eclectic cast of others, including Danger Mouse, Malay, DJ Kahlil and Jacknife Lee. Guests include Big K.R.I.T., Tom Morello, and RZA. 
Also out this week: 
Pop/rock — Demi Lovato likely named her new album "Confident" because she brought in hit machine Max Martin as her primary producer. The guy writes Top 10 singles while falling out of bed and then two more at breakfast. 
Louisville's Quiet Hollers take things to a new level on "Quiet Hollers"; “As If”; Josh Ritter, “Sermon on the Rocks”; Deerhunter, “Fading Frontier”; Here We Go Magic, “Be Small”; Pentatonix, “Pentatonix.” 
The Jokers is a rock 'n' roll band from Liverpool that's a complete throwback to 1976, built on swaggering vocals by Wane Parry and greasy guitar riffs from Paul Hurst. “Hurricane” is the band's third album and was released in the United Kingdom earlier this year, where it made rock hard rockers very happy. 
Speaking of vintage rock, the heavy metal icons in Saxon are back with “Battering Ram,” the English band's 21st album, and Stryper returns with “Fallen.” 
The Oh Hellos, “Dear Wormwood”; Alex Bleeker and The Freaks, “Country Agenda”; BØRNS, “Dopamine”; Christine and the Queens, “Christine and the Queens”; Majical Cloudz, “Are You Alone?"; Girls in Airports,“ Fables.” 
Tom Robinson, who crusaded for gay rights as a 1970s New Wave political power-popper, is back after a 20-year absence with “Only the Now,” which was funded by fans and features actor Ian McKellen. 
Supersuckers,“Holdin’ the Bag”; The Innocence Mission, “Hello I Feel the Same”; Michael Stanley, “And Then …”; Lisa Loeb, “Nursery Rhyme Parade!”; Yacht, “I Thought the Future Would Be Cooler”; The Mantles, “All Odds End”; State Champs, “Around the World and Back.” 
Sam Butler, former guitarist for Blind Boys of Alabama, goes solo with “Raise Your Hands!,” on which he covers modern spirituals written by secular artists such as Bruce Springsteen, Van Morrison, Tom Waits and The Bee Gees. 
R&B/hip-hop — Son Little, “Son Little"; Machine Gun Kelly, “General Admission.” Nikki Hill, “Heavy Hearts, Hard Fists”; OMI, “ME 4 U.” 
Country/bluegrass — The Charlie Daniels Band, “Live At Billy Bob’s Texas.” 
Christmas — Indie.Arie & Joe Sample, “Christmas With Friends”; The Brian Setzer Orchestra,“Rockin’ Rudolph”; KC and the Sunshine Band “A Sunshine Christmas”; LeAnn Rimes, “Today Is Christmas.” 
Reporter Jeffrey Lee Puckett can be reached at (502) 582-4160 and jpuckett@courier-journal.com. Read or Share this story: http://cjky.it/1RCfpAf TOP VIDEOS
